thread.title: Update / Weather Update: Slow warm up ahead
thread.title_full: Update / Weather Update: Slow warm up ahead

author: NewsBreak Original
title: Update / Weather Update: Slow warm up ahead
text: The National Weather Service (NWS) has lifted the Winter Storm Watch and Ice Storm Warning advisories for the region. The forecast calls for a slow warm up over the next several days. The NWS is forecasting mostly sunny conditions today, with a high near 41. East southeast wind 5 to 7 mph becoming north in the afternoon. Mostly cloudy, with a low around 30. East wind around 7 mph. Mostly sunny, with a high near 42. East wind around 10 mph. The Oregon Department of Transportation urges travelers to watch for icy roads and downed trees in the region. "Severe weather is forcing highway closures throughout northwest Oregon this weekend, including the Coast, Portland, and the Willamette Valley, as well as higher elevations. Stay home and reschedule your travel if possible," ODOT states in a release Update posted at 10:30 a.m. Jan. 14 The following is from the Oregon Department of Transportation. "We have extended closures throughout much of the lower Willamette Valley and Central Coast. U.S 20 at Newport is back open; however, the roads are extremely icy. "This list of closures is due to downed trees and powerlines. Closures include OR 126 milepost 14 to 41, Mapleton to west of Noti; OR 36 milepost 11 to 36, east of Swisshome to Triangle Lake; OR 229 milepost 0 to 31, south of Lincoln City to Toledo; and U.S. 20 milepost 32 to 72 Sweet Home to 2 miles east of Shea Viewpoint. "These closures are extremely challenging and rapidly changing. Closures could last several hours to several days. Severe weather is likely to hit again Tuesday and temperatures are not forecasted to get above freezing forcing highway closures throughout northwest Oregon, including the Coast, Portland, and the Willamette Valley, as well as higher elevations. Stay home and reschedule your travel if possible." Follow the latest weather developments at thenewsguard.com. Read More at http://thenewsguard.com
